Data.event_text: 1 January  Amendments to the National Defence Law take effect, transferring military powers from the State Council to the Central Military Commission, effectively giving Xi Jinping control over the military.

links.text: -Chan, Minnie (2021-01-03). "China's military takes charge of war powers with new defence law". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic The team sent by the World Health Organization to study the origins of the coronavirus pandemic virus is blocked from entering China. The team claims their visas had not been approved yet. Tedros Adhanom expressed his dismay, saying he had been in contact with senior Chinese officials, and how important the expedition was.

links.text: -Boseley, Sarah (2021-01-05). "China blocks entry to WHO team studying Covid's origins". The Guardian. Archived from the original on 2021-01-05. Retrieved 2021-01-06.-
-Boseley, Sarah (2021-01-05). "China blocks entry to WHO team studying Covid's origins". The Guardian. Archived from the original on 2021-01-05. Retrieved 2021-01-06.-

Data.event_text: Lai Xiaomin, former chairman of the China Huarong Asset Management, is sentenced to death for collecting bribes.

links.text: -"Ex-chairman of China Huarong Asset Management sentenced to death". Reuters. 2021-01-05. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 6 January  COVID-19 pandemic 11 million people are locked down in Shijiazhuang due to a COVID-19 outbreak.

links.text: -Cai, Jane; Siqi, Ji (2021-01-06). "Lockdown in Hebei provincial capital amid most daily Covid-19 cases in months". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 10 January  An explosion triggers a mining accident in Qixia, Shandong.

links.text: -Regan, Helen; Jeong, Sophie (2021-01-24). "11 of 22 Chinese miners trapped in gold mine rescued, ten others dead". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 11 January  COVID-19 pandemic 13 members of the 15 member World Health Organization team sent to study the origins of COVID-19 arrive in Wuhan, China. The last two members are awaiting in Singapore for their COVID-19 test results.

links.text: -"Health experts arrive in Wuhan to investigate COVID-19 origins". UN News. 2021-01-14. Retrieved 2021-05-01.-

Data.event_text: 14 January  COVID-19 pandemic The first recorded death from COVID-19 since May 2020 is reported in Hebei.

links.text: -"China records first Covid death since May as WHO team arrives in Wuhan". The Guardian. 2021-01-14. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 20 January  20202021 China–India skirmishes Chinese forces clash with Indian forces in Naku La.

links.text: -"Sikkim: Chinese and Indian troops 'in new border clash'". BBC News. 2021-01-25. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 22 January  East China Sea EEZ disputes China passes a law authorizing the China Coast Guard to fire on foreign vessels in the East China Sea.
30 January  The Hualong One nuclear reactor begins commercial operation.

links.text: -"China's first Hualong One nuclear reactor starts commercial operation". Reuters. 2021-01-30. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 2 February  ByteDance files a lawsuit against Tencent for monopolistic practices.

links.text: -"ByteDance's Douyin sues Tencent for monopolistic behaviour". Reuters. 2021-02-02. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 6 February  COVID-19 pandemic China approves the CoronaVac vaccine for general use.

links.text: -"China approves Sinovac Biotech COVID-19 vaccine for general public use". Reuters. 2021-02-06. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 7 February  China issues stricter anti-monopoly regulations to regulate internet platforms.
8 February  Clubhouse is blocked in China after increasing in popularity.

links.text: -"Clubhouse app blocked in China, added to 'Great Firewall': users, activists". Reuters. 2021-02-08. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 10 February  The Tianwen-1 orbiter and rover is inserted into orbit.

links.text: -Amos, Jonathan (2021-02-10). "China Mars mission: Tianwen-1 spacecraft enters into orbit". BBC News. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 11 February  The CCTV New Year's Gala attracts international controversy for the use of blackface.

links.text: -"China New Year gala show sparks new racism controversy with blackface performance". Reuters. 2021-02-12. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 15 February  A series of attacks are carried out on Chinese-owned factories in Myanmar as part of the 20212022 Myanmar protests.

links.text: -"Attacks on Chinese-run factories in Myanmar vex Beijing". AP NEWS. 2021-04-20. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 20 February  20202021 China–India skirmishes Chinese and Indian forces complete a withdraw from Pangong Tso after a months-long standoff.
22 February  The Parliament of Canada votes to recognize the Chinese persecution of Uyghurs as a genocide, becoming the second country to do so.

links.text: -"Canada's parliament declares China's treatment of Uighurs 'genocide'". BBC News. 2021-02-22. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic China approves the Convidecia and Sinopharm vaccines for general use.
The States General of the Netherlands votes to recognize the Chinese persecution of Uyghurs as a genocide.

links.text: -"Dutch parliament: China's treatment of Uighurs is genocide". Reuters. 2021-02-25. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 5 March  The 2021 National People's Congress begins.

links.text: -"A Guide to China's Biggest Political Meeting of 2021". Bloomberg. 2021-03-02. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 8 March  Several Chinese companies file a government-backed lawsuit against Adrian Zenz for his investigation of the persecution of Uyghurs in China.

links.text: -"China Backs Lawsuits Against German Researcher for Xinjiang Abuse Claims". www.bloomberg.com. 2021-03-09. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 11 March  The Chinese legislature grants a committee the power to choose which candidates are eligible for elections in Hong Kong.

links.text: -Glaun, Dan (2021-03-11). "China's Legislature Tightens Control Over Hong Kong Elections". PBS. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 15 March  Beijing is covered by the 2021 East Asia sandstorm.

links.text: -Neuman, Scott (2021-03-15). "Desert Dust Sweeps Into Beijing, Causing China's Worst Sandstorm In 10 Years". NPR. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 17 March  The European Union declares its first sanctions against China since 1989 in response to China's persecution of Uyghurs.
18 March  The United StatesChina talks in Alaska are held.
20 March  The recovery of hundreds of artifacts from a Sanxingdui dig site is announced.

links.text: -Chen, Stephen (2021-03-20). "Treasures from mystery civilisation could rewrite history of China". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: A suicide bombing occurs at a government land use office in Guangzhou.

links.text: -"China bomb attack kills four in suspected protest over development". the Guardian. Agence France-Presse. 2021-03-23. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: A diplomatic incident takes places between China and the Philippines when China stations hundreds of ships off the coast of Whitsun Reef.
27 March  China and Iran sign a 25-year Cooperation Program.
6 April  20202021 China–India skirmishes The Tibet Autonomous Region introduces 15 regulations on the border with India to limit entry.

links.text: -Chan, Minnie (2021-04-07). "China's 'new' border rules in Tibet point to same old dispute with India". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 10 April  Alibaba Group is fined 18 billion yuan ($2.75 billion USD).
11 April  COVID-19 pandemic China ends the mandatory vaccination policy of several localities amid vaccine hesitancy.

links.text: -"China Calls For Halt to Mandatory Vaccines Amid Inoculation Push". Bloomberg. 2021-04-11. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 27 April  An oil spill takes place off the coast of Qingdao.

links.text: -Neuman, Scott (2021-04-27). "Oil Spill Reported Off China Coast After Tanker, Bulk Carrier Collide". NPR. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 29 April  The Tianhe core module is launched into space as the first component of the Tiangong space station.
8 May  The rocket body from the Tianhe launch plunges into the ocean, prompting international concerns about safety measures for returning spacecraft.

links.text: -Howell, Elizabeth (2021-05-10). "China's huge rocket that fell from space highlights debris risk of uncontrolled reentries". Space.com. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 9 May  China deletes two million posts from the internet for their discussion of Chinese history.

links.text: -Mai, Jun (2021-05-11). "2 million posts deleted for 'historical nihilism' as party centenary nears". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: The Zhurong rover is the first Chinese craft to successfully land on Mars.
Tornadoes form in Wuhan and Shengze, killing 12 people.

links.text: -"Tornadoes hit two Chinese provinces, killing 12, injuring hundreds". Reuters. 2021-05-14. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 19 May  China bans the use or transfer of cryptocurrencies by banks, prompting Bitcoin to decline in value by nearly 30 percent.
20 May  Chinese industry sees significant economic turn down after China announces price controls on raw materials.

links.text: -"China's industrial commodities slide after Beijing warns of market crackdown". Reuters. 2021-05-20. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 21 May  A 6.4 magnitude earthquake occurs in Yunnan Province.

links.text: -"Quake in China's Yunnan province kills three, injures 28". Reuters. 2021-05-21. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 21 runners die from hypothermia in the Gansu ultramarathon disaster.

links.text: -Davidson, Helen (2021-05-28). "An ultramarathon ends in tragedy: runners describe horror of Gansu race". the Guardian. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: A 7.4 magnitude earthquake occurs in Qinghai.
The Zhurong rover successfully deploys on Mars.

links.text: -Woo, Ryan; Sun, Yilei (2021-05-22). "China says Martian rover takes first drive on surface of Red Planet". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 24 May  The funeral of Yuan Longping is attended by thousands of people.

links.text: -Wang, Amber (2021-05-24). "Large crowds gather for funeral of China's 'father of hybrid rice'". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 25 May  Thousands are evacuated in Shenzhen after SEG Plaza begins wobbling without apparent cause.

links.text: -Gan, Nectar (2021-05-19). "People flee in panic as skyscraper wobbles in China, despite no earthquake and fine weather". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 29 May  The Tianzhou 2 is launched into space and it docks with the Tiangong space station.

links.text: -Kharpal, Arjun (31 May 2021). "China completes another part of its own space station paving the way for astronauts to live there". CNBC. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 31 May  China replaces the two-child policy with the three-child policy to account for population decline.
1 June  The first human case of influenza A virus subtype H10N3 is documented in Jiangsu.

links.text: -Gu, Hallie; Patton, Dominique (2021-06-01). "China reports first human case of H10N3 bird flu". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 2 June  The June 4th Museum honoring the victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre is closed following a probe into its licensing status.

links.text: -"HK's June 4th museum temporarily closes over licensing probe". Reuters. 2021-06-02. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 4 June  COVID-19 pandemic The Sinovac vaccine is authorized for emergency use in children.

links.text: -"Sinovac's COVID-19 vaccine gains China nod for emergency use in kids, adolescents". Reuters. 2021-06-05. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 5 June  A man kills six people with a knife in Anqing.

links.text: -"Police in China apprehend suspect in knife attack that killed 6 and injured 14". Reuters. 2021-06-06. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 10 June  The Data Security Law of the People's Republic of China is enacted to regulate data collection by Chinese tech companies.

links.text: -"What U.S. Companies Should Expect from China's New Data Privacy Laws". JD Supra. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 13 June  A gas line explodes at a vegetable market in Shiyan, killing 25 people.

links.text: -"China Gas investigating cause of pipeline explosion in central China". Reuters. 2021-06-16. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: Shenzhou 12 carries Nie Haisheng, Liu Boming, and Tang Hongbo to the Tiangong space station.

links.text: -Garcia, Carlos; Wang, Shubing (2021-06-18). "Chinese astronauts board space station module in historic mission". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: The offices of the Apple Daily are raided and its assets are frozen.
25 June  A fire kills 18 students at a boarding school in Zhecheng County.

links.text: -"Fire at martial arts school in China kills 18 children". The Guardian. Agence France-Presse. 2021-06-26. Retrieved 2022-11-08.-

Data.event_text: 27 June  Chengdu Tianfu International Airport begins operation.

links.text: -Cripps, Karla (2021-06-27). "China's latest mega-airport is officially open". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 28 June  The Baihetan Dam begins generating hydroelectricity.

links.text: -"China starts Baihetan hydro project, biggest since Three Gorges". Reuters. 2021-06-28. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 30 June  WHO declares China to be malaria-free after four years without an indigenous case.

links.text: -"WHO declares China malaria-free after 70 years of efforts". DW. 2021-06-30. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 1 July  Celebrations are held for the 100th Anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party.

links.text: -"China Celebrates Its Communist Party's Centennial With Spectacle, Saber Rattling". NPR. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 5 July  Suning.com announces a bailout deal with the Jiangsu government and several other major corporations.

links.text: -Zhang, Jane (2021-07-06). "Chinese tech giants join US$1.4 billion state-led investment in Suning.com". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: China hosts the CPC and World Political Parties Summit.

links.text: -Tian, Yew Lun (2021-07-06). "China's Xi takes dig at U.S. in speech to political parties around world". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: The National Development and Reform Commission bans the construction of skyscrapers taller than 500 metres (1,600 ft).
7 July  Chinese conservation officials upgrade the conservation status of giant pandas from endangered to vulnerable.

links.text: -Pruitt-Young, Sharon (2021-07-09). "Finally Some Good News! China Says Giant Pandas Are No Longer Endangered". NPR. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 10 July  China blocks the merger of Huya Live and DouYu under Tencent.

links.text: -"Chinese antitrust regulator blocks Tencent's $5.3 billion video games merger". CNBC. 10 July 2021. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 12 July  The Siji Kaiyuan Hotel collapses, killing 17 people.

links.text: -"Hotel collapse in China's Suzhou kills 17, injures five". BBC News. 2021-07-14. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 13 July  Construction begins on Linglong One at the Changjiang Nuclear Power Plant, China's first small modular reactor.

links.text: -Xie, Echo (2021-07-16). "China starts construction of its first small modular reactor". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 19 July  Zhang Tao, chairman of China Aerospace International Holdings, is arrested and expelled from the company and the Communist Party for assaulting two senior scientists the previous month.

links.text: -Zheng, William (2021-07-20). "Head of China's aerospace investment firm arrested over alleged assaults". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 20 July  Typhoon Cempaka makes landfall in Guangdong.

links.text: -"Typhoon Cempaka makes landfall in China's Guangdong, says Xinhua". Reuters. 2021-07-20. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: China blocks Tencent from making exclusive music copyright agreements.
China announces a ban on private tutoring.
25 July  Typhoon In-fa makes landfall in China.

links.text: -"Typhoon In-fa makes landfall in China after record flooding". CNN. 2021-07-25. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 27 July  China conducts its first test of a Fractional Orbital Bombardment System, including the use of a Hypersonic Glide Vehicle.

links.text: -Sevastopulo, Demetri (2021-10-20). "China conducted two hypersonic weapons tests this summer". Financial Times. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 31 July  Singer Kris Wu is taken into custody in Beijing on suspicion of rape.

links.text: -Yeung, Jessie; Gan, Nectar (2021-08-17). "Pop star Kris Wu formally arrested in China on suspicion of rape". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 1 August  COVID-19 pandemic Millions of people in Beijing and other cities go into lockdown amid a COVID-19 outbreak.

links.text: -Davidson, Helen (2021-08-02). "Millions under strict lockdown in China after Covid outbreak". The Guardian. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 10 August  China severs diplomatic relations with Lithuania in response to the establishment of a Lithuanian embassy in Taiwan.
15 August  The Hong Kong rights group Civil Human Rights Front disbands.
20 August  The Personal Information Protection Law of the People's Republic of China is enacted.

links.text: -Horwitz, Josh (2021-08-20). "China passes new personal data privacy law, to take effect Nov. 1". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 23 August  The discovery of Bianchengichthys is reported following the excavation of its fossils.

Data.event_text: 2324 August  COVID-19 pandemic Thousands of people in Ruili are evacuated to Mangshi for a 14-day quarantine.

links.text: -Zheng, William (2021-08-27). "China evacuates thousands along Myanmar border to stop Covid-19". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 24 August  The Ministry of Education establishes new guidelines requiring Xi Jinping Thought to be taught in schools.

links.text: -"China to add 'Xi Jinping Thought' to national curriculum". Reuters. 2021-08-25. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 26 August  Dong Hong, former corruption investigator at the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, is put on trial for accepting bribes.

links.text: -Zheng, William (2021-08-27). "Former top corruption inspector charged with taking US$71 million in bribes". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-09.-

Data.event_text: 27 August  China establishes regulations on fan culture on the internet, including a ban on celebrity gossip. All content relating to actress Zhao Wei is removed from Chinese internet.
30 August  China bans children from accessing online video games outside of a designated periods that add up to three hours each week.
2 September  The National Radio and Television Administration bans the portrayal of effeminate men in media.

links.text: -McDonald, Joe (2021-09-02). "China bans men it sees as not masculine enough from TV". AP News. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 8 September  Francis Cui Qingqi is appointed as the bishop of Wuhan after an agreement between China and the Vatican.

links.text: -Lau, Mimi (2021-09-09). "Wuhan diocese finally gets new bishop under China-Vatican agreement". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 12 September  The 2021 Macanese legislative election is held, with most pro-democracy candidates declared ineligible by the Chinese government.

links.text: -"Macau democracy camp loses ground after legislative vote". ucanews.com. 2021-09-13. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 14 September  The Haidian District People's Court dismisses the sexual harassment case by Zhou Xiaoxuan against Zhu Jun.

links.text: -Rui, Guo (2021-09-15). "Chinese court rejects landmark #MeToo claim against TV host". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 16 September  A 6.0 magnitude earthquake occurs in Lu County, killing three people.

links.text: -"Southwest China earthquake collapses homes, kills at least 3". AP News. 2021-09-16. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 17 September  China applies to join the CPTPP.

links.text: -"China applies to join Pacific trade pact to boost economic clout". Reuters. 2021-09-17. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 19 September  The 2021 Hong Kong Election Committee Subsector elections are held with eligible candidates pre-approved by the Chinese government.

links.text: -Cheng, Sara; John, Alun (2021-09-19). "Hong Kong's first 'patriots-only' election kicks off". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: The unmanned Tianzhou 3 spacecraft launches to resupply the Tiangong space station.
Universal Studios Beijing opens to the public.

links.text: -Pollard, Martin Quin (2021-09-20). "Universal Studios Beijing draws eager throngs amid uneasy U.S.-China ties". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 22 September  Harbin goes into partial lockdown following an outbreak of COVID-19.

links.text: -"COVID-19 sends northern Chinese city into semi-shutdown". Reuters. 2021-09-22. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: Meng Wanzhou returns to China after being released by the United States and Canada in exchange for Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig.

links.text: -Kuo, Lily (2021-09-27). "China's release of 'Two Michaels' vexes country's online nationalists". The Washington Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: The Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China votes to dissolve itself.

links.text: -Lam, Jeffie; Wong, Natalie (2021-09-25). "Hong Kong group behind June 4 vigil passes resolution to disband". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 2 October  Former justice minister Fu Zhenghua is detained for violating party discipline.

links.text: -Ma, Josephine (2021-10-02). "Former Chinese justice chief held for Communist Party disciplinary probe". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 12 October  The National Development and Reform Commission announces that energy in China will be distributed through a market economy after government price controls lead to an energy crisis.

links.text: -Lee, Amanda; Xue, Yujie (2021-10-12). "Gripped by an energy crisis, China liberalises power pricing". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: Chinese H-alpha Solar Explorer, the first Chinese solar observation satellite, is launched.

links.text: -Zhen, Liu (2021-10-15). "China launches its first sun satellite to monitor solar eruptions". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: The 2021 CS Asian Open Figure Skating Trophy is held in Beijing.

links.text: -"2021 Asian Open Figure Skating Trophy". International Figure Skating. 2021-09-06. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 15 October  Shenzhou 13 carries Wang Yaping, Zhai Zhigang, and Ye Guangfu to the Tiangong space station.

links.text: -"New crew docks at China's first permanent space station". AP News. 2021-10-16. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: The Cyberspace Administration of China delists Caixin as an official news outlet.

links.text: -"China Cuts Caixin From Approved Media, Curbing Influence". Bloomberg. 2021-10-20. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: The Olympic flame arrives in Beijing for the 2022 Winter Olympics.

links.text: -Lew, Linda (2021-10-20). "Olympic cauldron lit in Beijing as protesters face court in Athens". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic Six COVID-19 cases prompt Lanzhou to go into lockdown.

links.text: -"China locks down city of 4m people after six Covid cases detected". The Guardian. 2021-10-26. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 20202022 Chinese property sector crisis Modern Land defaults on a bond payment, exacerbating the sector's debt crisis.

links.text: -Kwok, Donny; Galbraith, Andrew (2021-10-26). "China's Modern Land defaults on bond payment; property shares drop". Reuters. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 2 November  Tennis player Peng Shuai makes allegations of sexual assault against Zhang Gaoli, former Vice Premier of China and a high-ranking official of the Chinese Communist Party.

links.text: -Myers, Steven Lee (Nov 3, 2021). "A Chinese Tennis Star Accuses a Former Top Leader of Sexual Assault". New York Times.-

Data.event_text: 5 November  Former Vice Minister of Public Security Sun Lijun is arrested on charges of accepting bribes.

links.text: -Zheng, William (2021-11-05). "Ex-boss of China's secret police arrested on corruption charges". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 11 November  The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party memorializes Xi Jinping as a major historical figure in the Sixth Plenum.

links.text: -Kine, Phelim (11 November 2021). "Xi's Mao moment at the Sixth Plenum". Politico. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 12 November  The M+ art museum opens in Hong Kong to scrutiny amid increased censorship in the city.

links.text: -Chung, Stephy (2021-11-12). "Hong Kong's extraordinary M+ museum opens amid ongoing censorship fears". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: 21 November  Darryl O'Young wins the 2021 Macau Grand Prix.

links.text: -McNicol, Andrew (2021-11-21). "Hong Kong's O'Young seals miracle Macau Grand Prix win". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-10.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic 13 million people are put under lockdown in Xi'an after 52 cases are discovered in a COVID-19 outbreak.

links.text: -Yeung, Jessie (2021-12-23). "This Chinese city found a Covid cluster. All 13 million residents are now under lockdown". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: The Women's Tennis Association suspends all games in China in response to the treatment of tennis player Peng Shuai.

links.text: -Shivaram, Deepa (2021-12-01). "Women's Tennis Association suspends tournaments in China over concern about Peng Shuai". NPR. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index falls by 9.1 percent, the largest fall since 2008.

links.text: -Turner, Matt (2021-12-03). "China Stock Losses in U.S. Top $1 Trillion on Delisting Fear". Bloomberg. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: Chinese Olympic medalists perform in a goodwill tour in Hong Kong.

links.text: -McNicol, Andrew; Heung, Sammy; Sun, Fiona (2021-12-04). "Chinese Olympians wow Hong Kong crowds in multi-sport display". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 4 December  China hosts the International Democracy Forum after it is not invited to the Summit for Democracy.

links.text: -Hale, Erin. "China claims to have 'democracy that works' ahead of Biden summit". Al Jazeera. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 13 December  COVID-19 pandemic The first case of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant in mainland China is documented in Tianjin.

links.text: -"Mainland China detects first case of Omicron coronavirus variant -state media". Reuters. 2021-12-13. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 19 December  The 2021 Hong Kong legislative election takes places with candidates pre-selected by the Chinese Communist Party.
20 December  The People's Bank of China cuts its main interest rate for the first time in 20 months.

links.text: -He, Laura (2021-12-20). "China cuts key interest rate for the first time in 20 months". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 21 December  The discovery of a fossilized dinosaur embryo in China is reported.

links.text: -Hunt, Katie (2021-12-21). "Perfectly preserved baby dinosaur discovered curled up inside its egg". CNN. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 26 December  The Ziyuan I-02E satellite is sent into orbit.

links.text: -Huang, Kristin (2021-12-27). "China sends satellite into orbit to look for resources on Earth". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-

Data.event_text: 29 December  Stand News is shut down after its editors are arrested and its assets are frozen.

links.text: -Leung, Christy; Tsang, Emily; Yiu, William (2021-12-29). "Hong Kong's Stand News shuts down after 7 held, assets frozen". South China Morning Post. Retrieved 2022-11-11.-
